description:
Thamnophis sirtalis fitchi, also known as the Valley Garter Snake, is a subspecies of the Common Garter Snake (Thamnophis sirtalis) found in the Central Valley of California. This non-venomous snake is a member of the Colubridae family and is known for its slender build and distinctive coloration.

The Valley Garter Snake typically exhibits a greenish-brown or olive-green dorsal coloration, with three distinct longitudinal stripes running along its body. The lateral stripes are usually yellow or cream-colored, while the dorsal stripe is often a darker shade of the body color. The snake's ventral surface is typically a pale yellow or cream color.

This subspecies is adapted to a variety of habitats within the Central Valley, including grasslands, marshes, and riparian areas. They are active during the day and primarily feed on small rodents, amphibians, and invertebrates. The Valley Garter Snake is an important component of the ecosystem, serving as prey for larger predators and helping to regulate populations of smaller animals.

Thamnophis sirtalis fitchi is generally considered a subspecies of conservation concern, as its habitat has been impacted by human development and agricultural activities in the Central Valley. Conservation efforts, such as habitat preservation and management, are crucial for the continued survival of this unique garter snake subspecies.
